title: 114_s2125
content: The Act titled "Small Business Lending and Economic Inequality Reduction Act of 2015" includes a section on the Community Advantage Program. The Small Business Act is amended to include the Community Advantage Program, which defines covered institutions as development companies, nonprofit intermediaries, and certified community development financial institutions. The Community Advantage Program, established under the Small Business Act, includes covered institutions such as development companies, nonprofit intermediaries, and certified community development financial institutions. Reservists and service-connected individuals are also defined within the program. The term 'small business concern in an underserved market' refers to a small business located in a low- or moderate-income community, HUBZone, or designated empowerment zone. It must have over 50% of employees residing in a low- or moderate-income community and have been in existence for less than 2 years when a loan is made. The Community Advantage Program provides loans to small business concerns owned and controlled by veterans, service-disabled veterans, or individuals affiliated with the Armed Forces or Reservists. The Community Advantage Program guarantees loans for small businesses in underserved markets, with a maximum loan amount of $350,000. At least 60 percent of loans must go to small businesses in underserved markets. Regulations must be established within one year of enactment. The Administrator will promulgate regulations for a program similar to the Community Advantage Pilot Program, with a technical amendment to the Small Business Act. The Administrator will promulgate regulations for a program similar to the Community Advantage Pilot Program, with a technical amendment to the Small Business Act. The definition of a business concern is revised to exclude covered institutions as defined in section 7(a)(35)(A). Section 10(a) of the Federal Home Loan Bank Act is amended to include community development financial institutions in the purposes of advances and collateral available to financial institutions.
